sentences.sContent: The prime minister is now facing a revolt by members of his own party.
sentences.sCn: 首相现在面临着党内倒戈。

sentences.sContent: It was feared that the army would revolt against the government.
sentences.sCn: 有人担心军队会挥戈反对政府。

sentences.sContent: Some members of the government may revolt against this proposed legislation.
sentences.sCn: 一些政府成员可能会反对这项拟议中的法规。

remMethod.val: re(背)+volt(转)→把背转过来对着人→反抗

words.tran: 叛乱的；背叛的；讨厌的
背叛地；讨厌地；令人恶心地
反叛，造反；起反感（revolt的现在分词形式）

trans.tranOther: a refusal to accept someone’s authority or obey rules or laws
if people revolt, they take strong and often violent action against the government, usually with the aim of taking power away from them

sentences.sContent: an attorney who is a specialist in banking law
sentences.sCn: 一名专攻银行法的律师

sentences.sCn: 我卧室里的地毯是绿色的。

sentences.sContent: All the rooms had fitted carpets (= carpets cut to fit the shape of the rooms ) .
sentences.sCn: 所有的房间都铺了全室地毯。

synos.tran: 在…上铺地毯，把地毯铺在…上；斥责

phrases.pCn: （迎接贵宾用的）红地毯；隆重的接待
n. （《一千零一夜》中载人飞行的）魔毯；幻想中的神奇无比的交通工具

trans.tranOther: heavy woven material for covering floors or stairs, or a piece of this material
